stem: A laceration injures the superficial branch of the radial nerve on the dorsum of the wrist as it emerges from the brachioradialis. Which finding is most likely?

choices.A: Wrist drop from loss of wrist/digit extension
choices.C: Hypesthesia over the lateral dorsum of the hand and digits 1â€“3

rationale_correct: The superficial radial branch is purely cutaneous; injury produces sensory loss over the lateral dorsum of the hand without motor deficits.

rationale_distractors.A: Motor loss (wrist drop) reflects injury to radial motor fibers more proximally, not the superficial branch.
rationale_distractors.B: Elbow extension loss implies triceps involvement from a proximal/axillary radial lesion.
rationale_distractors.D: Thenar atrophy is median nerve (recurrent motor) pathology.
rationale_distractors.E: Pronation is mediated by median nerve (pronator teres/quadratus).

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb Lecture Notes. Sep 22, 2025.
